title: How to foster innovation and big thinking | Eeke de Milliano (Retool, Stripe)
key_insights: Process reduces variance but can bring high performers down to average - use minimum viable process with escape hatches
Innovation is blocked by fear of failure, urgent work overload, and lack of permission to think big
Build for your best users, not your worst users, especially in early product development
Use 70/20/10 resource allocation: 70% core product, 20% strategic initiatives, 10% experimental bets
Start new products with 1-2 person teams and treat them like funded startups within the company
Writing culture drives clear thinking - you can't be a good writer without being a clear thinker
Create structured moments for big thinking through 'Think Bigger' sections and 'Crazy Ideas' documents
Balance product talent portfolio with complementary skillsets rather than hiring in your own image
topics_discussed: Stripe's early culture and lack of initial PMs
Building Stripe Connect for marketplace business models
Developing Stripe Radar for fraud prevention
Stripe's operating principles: think rigorously, move with urgency and focus, customers first
Retool's three new product launches in 2022: Workflows, Mobile, and Database
Minimum viable process and giving high performers escape hatches
Build the scooter, not the axle approach to MVPs
Creating innovation through 'Crazy Ideas' documents and 'Think Bigger' planning sections
Product talent portfolio balancing different skillsets
Customer proximity through Slack channels and dogfooding
Difference between product-led and sales-led growth motions
When and how to introduce process at different company stages
Charter, goals, and roadmap as core documents for all organizational levels
Breaking the org for exceptional talent
memorable_quotes: Process, by definition, is variance reducing. You're introducing it because you worry that the variance in your org is too high... the cost is you're bringing other folks down to the average, and oftentimes those are your highest performers.
No one wakes up in the morning and thinks, 'Yeah, today I want to work on boring, incremental stuff.' But most teams do end up working on pretty incremental stuff.
Are you willing to break the org for this person? Some people are just that good that you'll break the org for them in the best way possible.
frameworks_mentioned: Build the scooter, not the axle MVP methodology
summary: Eeke de Milliano shares practical frameworks for fostering innovation while scaling product teams, drawing from her experience at Stripe and Retool. She provides actionable insights on balancing process with creativity, managing product talent portfolios, and creating organizational structures that enable big thinking and rapid product development.
